description: A versatile vegetable cultivated for its bulb. Onions are a staple in many cuisines worldwide, known for their pungent aroma and flavor when raw, which sweetens upon cooking.
origin: Central Asia (likely modern-day Iran or Pakistan)
seasons: Year-round (due to storage and different varieties)
healthBenefits: Contains antioxidants like quercetin, which may reduce inflammation and protect against chronic diseases.
Rich in sulfur compounds that can support heart health.
Can help regulate blood sugar levels.

potentialAllergies.name: Onion Intolerance/Allergy
potentialAllergies.details: Can cause digestive upset (gas, bloating) in some individuals. True allergy is rare but can cause skin rashes or asthma-like symptoms.

potentialAllergies.name: Fructan Intolerance
potentialAllergies.details: Onions are high in fructans, which can trigger IBS symptoms in sensitive people.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Planting: Can be grown from seeds, sets (small bulbs), or transplants. Plant in early spring for summer harvest or late summer/fall for overwintering in mild climates.
2. Soil: Prefer well-drained, fertile soil rich in organic matter with a pH of 6.0-7.0.
3. Spacing: Space sets 4-6 inches apart in rows 12-18 inches apart.
4. Watering: Requires consistent moisture, especially during bulb formation. Avoid waterlogging.
5. Weeding: Keep the area weed-free, as onions don't compete well with weeds.
6. Harvesting: Harvest when tops begin to yellow and fall over. Pull bulbs and cure them in a warm, dry, airy place for 1-2 weeks before storing.
growthDuration: 90-120 days from sets, longer from seed.
sustainabilityTips: Store whole, unpeeled onions in a cool, dark, dry place with good air circulation.
Use onion skins to make a natural dye or add to vegetable stock for color and flavor.
Grow your own from scraps: place the root end of an onion in water to sprout new greens.
carbonFootprintInfo: Relatively low, around 0.3-0.5 kg CO2e/kg, especially when field-grown and transported by land.

staticRecipes.name: Classic French Onion Soup
staticRecipes.description: A rich and savory soup made with caramelized onions, beef broth, and topped with toasted bread and melted cheese.
steps: Melt butter and olive oil in a large pot or Dutch oven over medium heat. Add sliced onions and sugar. Cook slowly, stirring occasionally, for 30-40 minutes, until deeply caramelized and golden brown.
If using, deglaze with white wine, scraping up any browned bits. Cook until wine reduces by half.
Add beef broth, thyme, and bay leaf. Bring to a simmer, then reduce heat and cook for at least 30 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper. Remove bay leaf.
Ladle soup into oven-safe bowls. Top with toasted baguette slices and a generous amount of grated cheese. Broil until cheese is melted and bubbly.

staticRecipes.name: Simple Onion Bhaji (Pakora)
staticRecipes.description: Crispy Indian fritters made with sliced onions and gram flour (besan).
ingredients: 1 tsp red chili powder (or to taste)
steps: In a large bowl, combine sliced onions, gram flour, rice flour (if using), ginger-garlic paste, turmeric powder, chili powder, ajwain, and salt.
Add a little water at a time and mix to form a thick batter that coats the onions well. Do not make it too runny.
Heat oil in a deep pan or kadai for frying.
Once the oil is hot, drop spoonfuls of the onion mixture into the oil. Do not overcrowd.
Fry on medium heat until golden brown and crispy, turning occasionally.
Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels. Serve hot with chutney.

staticRecipes.name: Quick Pickled Red Onions
staticRecipes.description: Tangy and vibrant pickled onions, great for tacos, salads, and sandwiches.
ingredients: 1/2 cup apple cider vinegar or white vinegar
Optional: Peppercorns, bay leaf, garlic clove
steps: Pack thinly sliced red onions into a clean glass jar.
In a small saucepan, combine vinegar, water, sugar, and salt. Add optional spices if using.
Bring the mixture to a boil, stirring until sugar and salt dissolve.
Pour the hot pickling liquid over the onions in the jar, ensuring they are fully submerged.

Let it cool to room temperature, then cover and refrigerate. They are ready to eat in about 30 minutes to an hour, but best after a few hours or overnight. Store in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

uses: Culinary base (raw, sautéed, caramelized, roasted, grilled for flavoring almost all types of savory dishes)
Soups (e.g., French onion soup), stews, curries
Spring onions/scallions (immature onions) used as garnish or vegetable

climaticRequirements.temperature: Temperate crop. Optimal for bulbing varies by day-length type: Long-day onions need 14-16 hrs daylight (10-25°C); Short-day need 10-12 hrs (20-30°C). Seed germination 10-25°C. Sensitive to frost during early stages, but some varieties can overwinter.
climaticRequirements.rainfall: Prefers 500-700 mm during growing season, or consistent irrigation. Good drainage is critical. Dry weather needed during bulb curing.
climaticRequirements.altitude: Can be grown from sea level to 2500m, depending on variety and day-length adaptation.

soilPreferences: Well-drained, loose, fertile loamy or sandy loam soils, rich in organic matter. pH 6.0-7.0 (slightly acidic to neutral). Heavy clay or compacted soils hinder bulb development.
irrigationWaterNeeds: Requires consistent moisture, especially during bulb formation and enlargement. Water stress can lead to small bulbs or splitting. Reduce irrigation as bulbs mature and tops begin to fall, to promote curing.
plantingHarvestCycles: Propagated from seeds (direct sown or transplanted), sets (small bulbs from previous season), or transplants. Planting time depends on day-length type and climate (spring or autumn). Bulbs mature in 90-150 days from seed, shorter from sets/transplants. Harvest when tops yellow and fall over. Bulbs are pulled or dug, then field-cured (dried) for 1-2 weeks before storage.
pestDiseaseManagement: Pests: Onion thrips (major pest), onion maggot, cutworms, nematodes. Diseases: Downy mildew, purple blotch, white rot (Sclerotium cepivorum - very persistent), pink root, neck rot (Botrytis - during storage). Integrated pest management (IPM) includes crop rotation (3-5 years), resistant varieties, sanitation, proper curing, and targeted chemical or biological controls.
postHarvestHandling: Curing is essential: dry bulbs in field (if weather permits) or in well-ventilated sheds until necks are tight and outer skins are dry and papery. Tops are then removed. Store in cool, dry, dark, well-ventilated conditions (0-4°C for long-term storage, with low humidity for storage onions, higher for sweet onions). Avoid storing with potatoes. Graded by size and quality.
marketValueGlobalDemand: Extremely high global demand as a fundamental ingredient in nearly all cuisines. Major internationally traded vegetable. Consumed fresh, cooked, and processed (dehydrated flakes/powder, pickled, frozen). Prices fluctuate based on global production, weather, and storage quality.
